_transcript.body:
Microsoft Teams is a hub for communication and collaboration. Where you can chat, call, have video meetings internally and externally as well work together on shared files.


Have you ever wondered what the difference is between calls, chats, Teams and Channels?  Calls and chats are great to have that private chat outside of the larger group maybe to work on a side project.


What about those large-scale projects, ongoing daily operations and keeping everyone informed? With a Team and its channels, you can setup a more robust workspace so everyone in your department or project will have the visibility into the bigger picture including the ability for all members to collaborate in one place. 


Another common question is what’s the difference between Teams and Channels. If you picture in your mind a house, so the team is like the house and channels are like the rooms in the house. So, the Team defines who has access: who are the owners, who are the members, and the house rules. The team gives everyone visibility and access.


Teams will be privet to all your team members, they all have a key to the house. Teams have owners who manage the settings and house rules.

All owners and team members contribute to the team, the running of the house.


Channels help organise information, like the rooms in your house. Channels help us focus our attention, we will have channels dedicated to a team within the department or maybe a specific topic for example a process or workstream of a role.


There are two types of channels standard channels all Team members have access. We also have private channels which are islands of security and only members of that channel having access. Channels bring together multiple workstreams to one Department Team.


And Let's not forget Microsoft Teams is accessible through your desktop application on your laptop or on you Remote Desktop, through a web browser on any device or even on your smart phone.  Which can really be useful for example if you lose your internet connection, you can still send that important department message on time using Teams on your smart phone and everything you do will be synced on all of your device.

title: Overview Video
instruction: Click play on the video to watch.
body: Microsoft Teams is a hub for communication and collaboration.

feedback.body: You are ready to unlock your next lesson. Use the Menu button bellow.
feedback.title: Simulation complete

intro.body: Learn how to navigate and organise your team list using this interactive Microsoft Team simulation.
intro.title: Welcome to the team list simulation

elements.ariaLabel: more options list showing leave the team
elements.title: Button leave the team

instructions.text: Click the Teams button on the left menu to access your team list.
You can now see the full list of the teams you are a member of on the left.
You can organise this list by hiding teams or moving them. Let’s start by hiding the teams you don’t use very often.
Click on More Options, the three dots … next to the Test & Build Team.
In the More Options menu, Click Hide, to hide the team.
The Test & Build team is now hidden from the list.
To view any hidden teams, you will need to select Hidden teams at the bottom of the team list.
To add any hidden team back to your viewable teams list you will use the More options button again.
Click More options next to the hidden Test & Build Team

graphic.alt: More options list and show button

instructions.text: This time in the more options menu click Show.
The Test and Build team is now back in your team list.
You can also organise the order of the teams in your team list. All you would need to do is drag & drop your team to the desired location in the list.
Click the Project City team and see it dragged to the top of the team list.
Sometimes you might need to join a new team, for example when you are working on a company project.
On these occasions you will need to have access to a new Team.  You will be notified if you are added to a new team, and it will appear in your team list.
You also could be invited to join a team with a code.
If you are provided with a code, go to the bottom of your team list, and click on Join or create a team.

hint.text: Press Enter on your keyboard after entering the team code.

instructions.text: You have been given a code to join the People Department Team.
Enter the code 4xc420n, and then click Enter on your keyboard.
Now click the Join team button
Now you can see your new People Department team in the team list.
Finally, if you no longer need to be a member of any team you can choose to leave it.
Click More options next to the People Department team.
Note: If you do leave a team you will need to request the owner of that team to provide you access again.
You are happy to leave this team so click Leave the team option in the menu.
The team will automatically be removed from your team list.

feedback.body: You are ready to unlock your next lesson. Use the Menu button bellow.
feedback.title: Simulation complete

intro.body: Learn how to navigate and organise your channel list using this interactive Microsoft Team simulation.
intro.title: Welcome to the channel list simulation

instructions.text: You would open a Team to view the channels. Let's have a look at the channels in the Test and Build Team.
Click on the Test & Build Team on the left in your team list.
You can see all the standard channels and private channels which have a lock icon next to them, available to you in the team.
The list of channels is in alphabetical order except for the General channel which will always be at the top of the list.
Unlike your team list you cannot change the order of channels they are fixed. However, you can hide channels.
Move your mouse pointer over to the Legal Technical channel and click on the three dots to access the More options menu.
Click Hide to hide the channel from your channel list.
You can see any hidden channels in the hidden channel section at the bottom of the channel list.
Click on 1 hidden channel at the bottom of the channel list.
Here you can view the channel or add it back to your main channel list.
Click on Show next to the hidden Legal Technical channel.
The Legal Technical channel can now be seen back in your channel list.
If you have a channel that you want easy access to you can pin it to the top of the team list.
Move your mouse pointer over to the Team Ace channel and click on the three dots to access the More options menu.
In the More options menu click on Pin.
You can now see the channel at the top of the team list for easy access.
As well as Microsoft Teams having an overall notification setting, you also have control of notifications on each channel.
Move your mouse pointer over to the Superusers channel and click on the three dots to access the More options menu.
Click Channel notification.
You can choose to have all posts, replies, and mentions turned on or off or customise the notifications for the channel.
Turn off the notifications for this channel.
You will know there are new posts in the channel when the channel name is bold, leaving you the option to view the posts when you want to and without any notifications.

_items.backText:
Standard Channels

Every member of the team has access to all standard channels. By default, every team will have a General channel which is used as the main go to area. Like using a group email, you can use the general channel to communicate and collaborate with all the members of a team. All members of the team will see the communications and can collaborate.

Other channels will be used for specific workstreams that every member needs access to.

Private Channels

These are closed to all members of the team so not everyone inside that team will have access. Private channels are used for individual teams and other closed work groups in your department. 

Each private channel will have at least one owner who set the channel up and they have control of who has access to the private channel.

title: Channel Type Flip Card
instruction: Click the cards to flip it and reveal more information about each type of channel
ariaLabel: Click the cards to flip it and reveal more information

_graphic.alt: Showing Team Channel Post Tab and Tools

_items.body:
The post tab is where you communicate with the rest of the channel members. You will notice as you start to use channels there will be lots of conversations but not all conversations will be related to each other. 


  • Reply  - For the sake of keeping topics organised you will see a Reply button at the bottom of each thread to keep that conversation going without overlapping, unlike in a team chat.


  • Notifications - What you can also do, which is not available in chats, is turn off notifications for yourself on a post. This won’t impact the settings for other people in the channel. Select More options (...) next to the post > Turn off notifications.


  • Attachments - documents can be attached as a copy or a link and are viewable in the channel by all members (note any copied documents will also be available on the channel File tab).


If you open the conversation box A  to access the formatting tools you will also have access to:

  • Announcements - Using a banner at the beginning of the conversation can make a headline in the channel post.
  • Who can reply - If you want to limit who can reply to your post you can choose only you and moderators can reply instead of everyone.
  • Post to multiple channels - If this is an important announcement that needs posting across different team channels you can go ahead and do that too.
_items.title: Posts

_graphic.alt: Showing Team Channel File Tab and Tools

_items.title: File
_items.body:
In Microsoft Teams, there are diverse ways to find, store, and share files to collaborate with others. Inside a channel files and documents can be accessed by all members of that channel. 


  • Upload and create file - You can upload files directly to the Files tab in any channel. Just click Files at the top, then click Upload. To create a new file, click New.


  • Work with files - In the Files tab or a team conversation, select More options (...) > Open next to the file and choose if you want to edit the file in Teams, on your desktop, or online. 


  • SharePoint - Files that you upload to a channel are stored in your team's SharePoint folder. To access SharePoint files and folders for a channel, go to the channel and tap Files > Open in SharePoint.


  • Make this a tab - If you use a file often why not go to the file you want and select More options (...) > Make this a tab, giving you access to the file on the channel toolbar.


  • Pin - Another way to find files easily is to pin them to the top of the file list, select More options (...) > Pin.


For more help with saving and working with files watch these short videos:

  • Work on a File Together
  • Saving Your Work

Every channel has a Wiki, and it is great to use for key points and notes that can get lost in the flow of conversation. The Wiki tab is a smart-text editor that doubles as a communication machine where you draft, edit, and chat all in one place. 


Co-Authoring - After someone creates a wiki tab, another team member can add more content, edit the content, or add supporting links. The community of authors helps to ensure the accuracy and relevance of the content. Wikis continue to evolve as people add and revise information.


Editing - Every document in your Wiki tab is called a page and every page is made of different sections. To get started, give your page a title and then start authoring sections. Any time you want to add a new section, just hover over the left side of the page, and select Add a new section here.


Table of Contents - On the left side of your screen, you'll see a Table of Contents. This helps you navigate quickly between pages or even do some organising.


Chat from your Wiki tab - To talk with a teammate about a page, @mention them in a section. This comes in handy when you want feedback or you're waiting on someone else to contribute a section to your page. If commenting directly in a section isn't your style, you can always start a conversation in the tab itself by selecting Show section conversation.
_items.title: Wiki
Apps
_items.body:
Online applications, (Apps) let you do more in Teams. Think about the tools, files, and dashboards your department already uses. Many of them can be added right into Teams using the Plus symbol on your channel toolbar.


You have Microsoft apps and some third-party apps. Please be aware not all these are free and may require subscriptions. 


Why not start by using some of the below suggested apps:


  • Website - One especially useful app that gets overlooked, allowing you to add a webpage as a tab on your channel for all members to access and use.


  • Task by Planner and To Do - Tasks makes it easy to stay organised across all your Planner and To Do tasks. Create, assign, and track tasks individually or collaboratively with your team, and see everything come together in one place. 


  •  Miro - Miro is the online whiteboard platform that helps you co-create and bring meetings to life. Instantly open a Miro board right in any Teams meeting to brainstorm ideas, take notes, or visualize concepts together and add to your channel toolbar as a tab. 


  • Polly - Lets you take quick polls during a meeting, direct messaging, and even group conferences. It provides unlimited polls in the form of multiple choices, Yes or No, ratings-based polls, etc.


  • Praise - available in any standard channel, the Praise app helps you show appreciation to other members of your team. With a selection of badges to choose from, Praise is designed to help recognise the effort of your team members.

_items.title: Meet
_items.body:
You can start a meeting straight from within your channel where all the members will be contacted with one click. 


  • Click the Meet button in the top right corner.


You can also schedule a meeting with all your team members from any standard channel.


  • Select the Meet drop-down menu in the top-right corner.
  • Select Schedule a meeting.


The meeting will get posted in the channel, it'll appear under the Posts tab. Team members can set agendas, share files, or add comments.


Use the Manage Meetings resource to find out how to complete a meeting request in Teams.

_items.title: Bookmark a message
_items.body: You can bookmark any post so it’s easy to find later. Click on the more options (...) in the top left corner of the post and select Save this message. To view your saved messages, go to your Profile picture in the top right and select Saved.

_items.title: Send message by email
_items.body:
If a message is relevant to others who are not a member of the team channel you can send the message by Outlook email.

Click on the More options (...) in the top left corner of the message and select Share to Outlook.

_items.title: Translate a message
_items.body: You can translate any message in Teams. This option is super useful when working with multilingual coworkers. Click on the More options (...) in the top left corner of the message and select Translate.

_items.title: Search bar commands
_items.body: The search bar at the top of Teams is also a command bar. You can perform a lot of actions using the / commands from here. Type / in the search bar or instead of clicking into the search bar you can use the Ctrl + / command to move the focus to the search bar and list out all the available commands.

body:
There are more help topics available in our HF development platform Looop. Why not check them out and get the best out of your teams and channels.


These are only a few of the Microsoft Team resource available visit Microsoft Teams (looop.co) to see the full list.

_items.body:
Did you know Teams has its own area to go to for help? Head to the bottom of the team menu and you will find the Help icon. 

Then you have some options to choose for further assistance:
Search for help by Topic, find out What's New in Microsoft Teams and Further Training.

title: Notification Text
body:
So, you don't miss any communication in your new Department Team & Channels we advise you turn on All Activity on your desktop to see all new messages, activities and mentions when added.


To access your individual notifications settings:

  • Selecting the three dots' (...) Settings & More, next to your profile picture in the top right corner of your Microsoft Teams.
  • Click Settings and a pop-up window will appear
  • Select Notifications
  • Look for the Teams & Channels section and then select All Activity
